Posts.EditableText:
It was only a front-end design as CW said, but I'm pretty sure I can work on something similar and get it working.  I'm gunna be writing some small programs first.  They'd be pretty pointless though since most things you can do with QDK, but it wouldn't do any harm to learn how to make programs that write ASL code.

About a year ago I was thinking of writing my own client, but I'll have to talk with Alex about that.

Posts.EditableText: If you can get any code out of him, that'd be ace . I know I'm doing a C++ version, but it's hella hard to do it all 'correctly'. And as for some front-end stuff, I guess it'd be cool.. Just as long as it isn't trying to imitate QDK at all. I tried a coders part, which I wanted to have sort-of-macros in which pasted most of the room stuff for me to customise etc.. Room placement on a map would be nice I guess.. Other than that I'm stumped for ideas right now.

Posts.EditableText: Anything I make, I'll release the source code with it. After all, Quest Centre is a learning resource. I'll begin on small things first, and practice on getting the software to write basic ASL code, then perhaps move on to more complicated scripts. What I'm really aiming for is a completely new client, designed for click-based play. You know how I LOVE click-based laziness
Posts.HTML:

Posts.EditableText:
Do people have that much of a boring life to not have the ability to move on?  I find it a common problem with anti-social people.

The said "game" i work on, and change the name for "1,000,000" times is something I do in my free and spare time whenever i don't have anything better to do, which to be honest, isn't very often.

But I don't give a shit about that, so I won't comment on it any further.  It's sad though that you still have to bring it up.  You should try making friends and going outside in the sun once in a while, you might find that starting conversations about interesting things comes naturally after a few tries.
